74492: Tomb of Urami.author: Henrietta
74492: Tomb of Urami.text_parsed:
If you would like to understand why this card is rated so lowly despite being good in competitive Magic, consider the fact that gatherer ratings are made by casual players, not competitive players. There are for more casual players viewing gatherer pages than skilled competitive players who know anything at all about playing Magic. What casual player wants to sacrifice all of his lands AND take damage? Casual players vehemently hate paying for effects, and sacrificing all of your lands is especially harsh, so it's difficult for them to appreciate a card like this. Someone from R&D talked about this in an article. I don't remember the exact example they used, but it went something like this. If you have a Grizzly Bears (1G, 2/2, no abilities) and another card (1G, 2/2, sacrifice it: gain 1 life) side by side, casual players in general would pick the Grizzly Bears, even though the second card is strictly better. Casual players avoid life loss effects in a similar manner, even on very powerful cards.

For anyone interested in getting better at Magic rather than making terrible suggestions as to how to make this card completely broken (DarthParallax's suggestion that you should be able to use it on turn one was especially humorous), I will explain why this card is good.

Simply put, it's because it's a land. If this were a creature that cost 2BB and involved you sacrificing your lands, it would deserve the rating it has. However, it's not. Lands that also function as spells are extremely powerful. In many games, this will just be a Swamp with a minor drawback. The drawback is minor because life is used as a resource in competitive Magic - it doesn't matter if you win the game with 1 life left or 20. In other games, however, it will win the late game for you, when each player has exhausted their resources, you will be able to make a 5/5 flier to end the game. When each player has no important creatures on the board and no or few cards in hand, this will be able to win the game, whereas the other player just has a basic Swamp in play that isn't doing much game winning for him.

Lands with spell-like effects are inherently powerful. They give you one more spell to kill your opponent with, while still being a land that simply prevents you from being manascrewed. The cost to use this is small, but the upside is high.

74492: Tomb of Urami.author: DeviousPie
74492: Tomb of Urami.text_parsed:
The rating on this card depresses me. It's essentially a swamp that can be used late game as a finisher.
Suicide black decks play their hands extraordinarily quickly. This card provides no tempo loss and doesn't take any slots that would otherwise go to spells. If you have three lands and a dark ritual, an evasive fatty will help you out far more than those otherwise wasted lands.
Remember: your life total, your mana base, the number of permanents you have, the number of cards in your library, and the number of toes you have DON'T matter so long as you have won.

T2 - Dredge him again. Songs of the damned and pop it, drop your second land if you have one. They need to answer a 5/5 flyer now. It *did* cost you a couple cards; but eating 5 to the face if you don't cast removal is a terrible thing; especially because that's going to be followed up by a Tombstalker.

May find a home in pox/dredge if such a thing can exist.

Also, Planar Birth can fix that problem. Use this ability, sac your lands, make your land drop, make next turns land drop, and you're good to go, only 1 land behind.

Consider using it with Balance or Restore Balance as well

74492: Tomb of Urami.author: EvilDarkVoid
74492: Tomb of Urami.text_parsed:
This is actually a very solid card and imo its rating should be more in the 3-4 star range. Let me explain.

As with the Invoker cycle, many people look at the heavy cost and say, "You'll never realistically use that in a game. You'll always win or lose before then!" Those are optimistic people. Sometimes neither you nor your opponents draw the right cards to win the game quickly. Sometimes one or both of you has lots of answers to the other person's stuff and the game gets nowhere. Tomb or Urami can be a major piece in your deck, like if you combine it with Balance, but it doesn't have to be. I'm going to let you in on a secret: a single Tomb of Urami is pretty good in nearly every black deck. 1 life is really not that big a drawback; prioritize tapping your other lands first and the life loss often going to be negligible. And when your opponent "stabilizes" at 5 or less life, having wiped your board with Wrath of God after you've played all of your threats, activate this thing at the end of their turn and finish them off with it. Its hard to block, hard to burn, some common black removal fails to hit it, and sorcery speed removal in general won't stop it from hitting for at least 5.

A Lava Axe that requires you to sac all of your lands is not good. A land which acts totally normal and then Lava Axes your opponent in the face to finish them off is very good, and if your opponent has used all of their removal then it can do even more than that.

74503: Spiraling Embers.author: endersblade
74503: Spiraling Embers.text_parsed:
Vexing Shusher. Counterspell problem solved.

Obviously works best in a deck that draws a lot of cards, and blue has that in spades. So you'll probably have your OWN counterspells to counter theirs. Draw a gigantic hand, Vexing shusher this thing, then blow your opponent up. I have a mono-red deck that plays 4 Font of Mythos. My opponents usually laugh when I drop them. "Cool, I'll draw into what I need to finish you off quickly. Thanks!" Then I drop a couple of these and the game's over.

Sure, it's a casual deck. I'm sure it wouldn't hold up in a legacy tourney at all, but it's still fun to play in my circle. Usually after I've dropped the Shusher and one or two fonts, my opponents usually say, "GG, switch decks!"

74509: Sakashima the Impostor.author: will_dice
74509: Sakashima the Impostor.text_parsed:
@DavidLopes - yes, you can copy a creature-fied planeswalker. But Sakashima also copies the planeswalker's subtype (on your example, it would be "Planeswalker - Tezzeret"), so both Sakashima and original Tezzeret will go to the graveyard before you have the chance to use any of Sakashima's walker abilities.

Sakashima ignores the legend rule because it keeps its own name, but the planeswalkers rule looks at the subtype.

74509: Sakashima the Impostor.author: strider24seven
74509: Sakashima the Impostor.text_parsed:
@atemu1234

Your question is moot- but I understand what you are trying to ask.

Let us say for example that you have a Jace Beleren, upon which you use Argent Mutation on, and a March of the Machines in play.

At this point, Jace Beleren is an 3/3 Blue Artifact Creature Planeswalker-Jace with CMC 3, 3 loyalty counters (assuming you haven't used any of his abilities yet) and 3 loyalty abilities. At end of turn, he would return to simply being a Planeswalker-Jace with CMC 3, 3 loyalty counters, and 3 loyalty abilities.

Now, before end of turn, let us say you play Sakashima the Imposter, entering play as a copy of Jace Beleren.
Sakashima is a 3/3 Legendary Blue Artifact Creature Planeswalker-Jace named Sakashima the Imposter with CMC 3, 3 loyalty counters, and 3 loyalty abilities, and the activated ability "2UU: Return this creature to its owner's hand at end of turn" and will remain that way permanently.
What happens to the orignal Jayce Beleren is unimportant at this point- Sakashima will forever be treated as a 3/3 Legendary Blue Artifact Creature Planeswalker-Jace with CMC 3 and 3 loyalty abilities and 1 activated ability. From now on, for all intents and purposes, Sakashima doesn't care what happens to Jace Beleren.

However, most of this is irrelevant- immediately after entering play, both Sakashima and Jace would be put into the graveyard at the same time as a state-based action due to the planeswalker rule.

74509: Sakashima the Impostor.author: BrokenAllies
74509: Sakashima the Impostor.text_parsed:
I just want to tell a little tale of my recent adventures with Sakashima.

I was in a "grand melee" ( 6 player EDH game ), with five of my friends.

I was playing my favorite deck, a blue and black Mill and Clone deck, championed by none other than Lazav, Dimir Mastermind . The basic concept of the deck is to mill people, generally have a good time and then let Lazav become whatever falls into peoples graves.

Fortune struck and one of my friends where forced to discard his hand. In that hand, he had a little lass called Avacyn, Angel of Hope .
Well... Now I had an angel commander called Lazav, Dimir Mastermind, Angel of Hope. ( Funny side note about this is that Lazav, even though he spends month, tracking and researching people that he want to imitate, he still INSISTS on being called, Lazav... which, I would think, undermindes the entire operation.)

I was soon getting the attention of the board, what, with my army being indestructible. So I so no other way out, than to call in the big guns.

Enter Sakashima, The Imposter.

Now I had TWO Angels of Hope. One named Lazav, Dimir Mastermind, Angel of Hope. And even better! I now had:

Sakashima, The Imposter, Dimir Mastermind, Angel of Hope.

You see. To understand the greatness of Sakashima, you have to understand that it isn't enough for the Imposter to imitate whatever Lazav was doing. Oh no... Sakashima had to BE Lazav, BEING Avacyn, thereby perfectioning the disguise.

Long story short. I won. Great times.

Next time, I will tell you about the time Sakashima became Emrakul, the Aeons Torn . But that is a tale for another time... but... I'll let you think about it for a moment.. how Sakashima convinced everyone that he was an Eldrazi... how gullible are people?

74604: Reki, the History of Kamigawa.author: Corey_bayoudragonfly
74604: Reki, the History of Kamigawa.text_parsed: @bijart_dauth: Both Leyline of Singularity and Enchanted Evening only change permanents to being legendary/enchantments. Reki here cares about when you cast a legendary spell: it does not become legendary until it hits the field, by which point it is no longer a spell and cannot trigger Reki, unless it was legendary to begin with.
74604: Reki, the History of Kamigawa.text_posted: @bijart_dauth: Both [autocard]Leyline of Singularity[/autocard] and [autocard]Enchanted Evening[/autocard] only change [i]permanents[/i] to being legendary/enchantments.  Reki here cares about when you cast a legendary [i]spell[/i]: it does not become legendary until it hits the field, by which point it is no longer a spell and cannot trigger Reki, unless it was legendary to begin with.

74618: Iname as One.author: Milliman
74618: Iname as One.text_parsed:
Awesome play with this would go

1. Get 12 mana before you die.... Hard part over
2. Play iname as one (this card), search your library for iname, death aspect. Put every single spirit creature in your graveyard, including myojin of life's web and iname, life aspect.
3. On your next upkeep sac/destroy iname as one, put iname, life aspect on the battlefield, put all those "big beater spirits" in your hand and then play the myojin, remove the counter and toss them all out.
4. Get haste and start beating people!

74618: Iname as One.author: Fireballmage
74618: Iname as One.text_parsed:
:-(

The Iname story is my favorite Kamigawa vignette; it has epic scope, a sympathetic-yet-flawed character, and a great illustration of one of life's harder lessons. For those looking, the story can be found at this URL.
http://www.wizards.com/Magic/TCG/Article.aspx?x=magic/chk/iname

So when I learned there was a combined Iname, I wondered what the story would do with it... And yet we got nothing. Worse, the card is awful, both as a regular card and as an EDH general, so it's impossible for me to look at it without thinking of the wasted potential.
74618: Iname as One.text_posted:

75340: Pain's Reward.author: roguepariah
75340: Pain's Reward.text_parsed:
My question is how does this interact with platinum emperion?

Specifically, can you "bid" life if your life total can't change?
Rules say you can't pay costs that involve changing your life, but bidding isn't a cost here as far as I can tell.

So with an emperion on the table can you bid more life than your opponent has and keep your life when pain's reward resolves?
75340: Pain's Reward.text_posted:
My question is how does this interact with [autocard]platinum emperion[/autocard]?

Specifically, can you "bid" life if your life total can't change?
Rules say you can't pay costs that involve changing your life, but bidding isn't a cost here as far as I can tell.

So with an emperion on the table can you bid more life than your opponent has and keep your life when [autocard]pain's reward[/autocard] resolves?

75340: Pain's Reward.author: DacenOctavio
75340: Pain's Reward.text_parsed:
@ roguepariah:

You just broke this card. Congrats! Bidding life is not the same as paying life, and you only lose life and draw the cards if your bid is the highest number. Platinum Emperion's rule is like a replacement effect, so you don't lose the life for drawing the cards. Now, the challenge is building a deck that not only cheats Emperion into play early enough for resolving Pain's Reward to matter, but keeping your Emperion on the board and under your control as Pain's Reward resolves.

Proof, taken from Platinum Emperion's ruling:

1/1/2011 Spells and abilities that would normally cause you to gain or lose life still resolve, but the life-gain or life-loss part simply has no effect.
75340: Pain's Reward.text_posted:
@ roguepariah:

You just broke this card. Congrats! Bidding life is not the same as paying life, and you only lose life and draw the cards if your bid is the highest number. [autocard]Platinum Emperion[/autocard]'s rule is like a replacement effect, so you don't lose the life for drawing the cards. Now, the challenge is building a deck that not only cheats Emperion into play early enough for resolving [autocard]Pain's Reward[/autocard] to matter, but keeping your Emperion on the board [i]and[/i] under your control as Pain's Reward resolves.

Proof, taken from [autocard]Platinum Emperion[/autocard]'s ruling:

1/1/2011	Spells and abilities that would normally cause you to gain or lose life still resolve, but the life-gain or life-loss part simply has no effect.

75340: Pain's Reward.author: Blind_Piper
75340: Pain's Reward.text_parsed: @DacenOctavio: Players don't bid until the spell starts to resolve. By that point, there's no spot between bidding life and losing life for players to gain priority. So, if you've reached bidding life and your Platinum Emperion is still alive, you're safe.
75340: Pain's Reward.text_posted: @DacenOctavio: Players don't bid until the spell starts to resolve. By that point, there's no spot between bidding life and losing life for players to gain priority. So, if you've reached bidding life and your [autocard]Platinum Emperion[/autocard] is still alive, you're safe.

75340: Pain's Reward.author: iUseBreakOpen
75340: Pain's Reward.text_parsed:
Fantastic synergy in Liliana's Caress decks where one of the biggest problems is having your opponent run out of cards to discard. Unfortunately, that's the only situation that I can think of that makes this card worth playing.

Yes, you would get mad johnny points for cheating a Platinum Emperion into play to use with this card, but it's too many hoops to jump through for not that strong of an effect.

Using it in conjunction with Children of Korlis or Tainted Sigil is cool, but it still boils down to using 4 mana and 2 cards (or 7 mana and 2 cards) to draw 4 cards.

On its own, this card inherently gives the advantage to your opponent. Why? Whether you win the bid or lose the bid, you are out 3 mana and a card. To think of it another way:

If you win the bid, then you're up 3 cards (you used 1 card to draw 4).
If they win the bid, then they're up 5 cards (they get 4 cards and you're out 1 card).
And either way you're out 3 mana which could have been spent on something else.

Most of the people in my play group realize that a difference of 8 cards is on the line AND that a difference of 8 cards is worth far more than a few life points. They consistently bid as high as 8 life and even when you try to build your deck to quickly put them in a position where bidding that much life is unwise, the fact that you have this card in your hand means that your opponent is likely to have one more card than you do to ensure that it is YOU who is in a position where it is unwise to bid that much life.

78585: Bounteous Kirin.author: Mode
78585: Bounteous Kirin.text_parsed:
Kamigawa design team logic (assumed scenario how the mana cost came to be):

"Alright, this Kirin cycle is looking pretty good so far. Flying Hill Giants with an interesting Spiritcraft mechanic."
"Was it the green or the white one that makes you gain life again? It makes for potentially decent lifegain from midgame onwards. Dangerous stuff right there, especially considering Spirits are such a competitive thing right now. We better bump that mana cost."
"Like the blue one? I'm glad we changed it from the rest into an Air Elemental instead. The milling mechanic was clearly too good on a four-drop with powerhouses like Dampen Thought around. Or just imagine someone using it on himself to make use of Soulshift. We can't have that tech as early as turn five!"
"Right, we all know how powerful Spiritcraft decks these days are already. Just think of all those crazy broken Soulshift cards we made... Just think of Harbinger of Spring, that's just utterly broken against non-Spirit decks.
"Dude, they're all above the curve. I could list visually all of them: Hundred-Talon Kami, Pus Kami, Deathknell Kami, Burr Crafter, Kami of Lunacy, Torii Watchward, Kami of the Honored Dead, Vine Kami, Body of Jukai..."
"STOP! Please, it's painful to remember. One more broken than the next! They must be dominating the format now."
"Well, I wouldn't be surprised about that with bombs like Crawling Filth around! What were we thinking?"
"Oh man, these are so blatantly above the curve. I'm still ebarrased about that."
"That's why we have to be so careful about these Spirits in Saviors now! It's our last chance to redeem ourselves, and we don't want to break Spirit decks even more than they already are!"
"True! But I think we've done a good job so far. Let's give us a pet on the back for the Onna cycle we've done so far. Their increased cost really keeps the self-bounce under control."
"Yeah, your suggestion of increasing their cost like we did with the Eidolon cycle in Betrayers really helped."
"And we're almost done adjusting the Kirin cycle now. Blue one aside, I like how the red one started with a Threaten mechanic, but then removed the haste part for balancing reasons. Almost made a competitive card there, haha."
"I know right? Inciting kitchen table misplays instead seems far more hilarious."
"Can we get back to that lifegain Kirin please? I'm still really concerned about that."
"Yeah you're right. Let's adapt it to the blue one."
"And potentially gain life as early as turn six? Are you crazy?!"
"Oh yeah, right. Better go from to then."
"You mean to . We made the white one a 'holy wrath'-flavored Engineered Explosives for some reason.
"Uhm. You guys, I know we had Jugan in this block, but flying isn't really green's thing..."
"Good point! it is!"
"Shouldn't we at least adjust the P/T or something?"
"Just seconds ago we talked about the format-warping Spirit decks. Do I really have to recite the list of broken Soulshift creatures to you? Never mind the boost they'll get from other new Spirits like Fiddlehead Kami."
"No, please! I'm sorry for asking. You're right. It's fine."

Also important is that only the green and blue kirin have non-conditional abilities. You always get a bonus burst of life with each spell. This card isn't great, but its good by Kamigawa standards.

79164: Akki Underling.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
79164: Akki Underling.text_parsed:
@The_Trendkill: That's probably a perfect evaluation!

Saviours was a pretty "meh" set to me - it's not terribly interesting to have to sit around not playing your spells just so that you could have a high card count in your hand. I figured this guy was part of a cycle so I went looking for other cards that give you a bonus for having seven or more cards in hand... only to find that it was a two card cycle where the other card is Deathmask Nezumi. An ability like this would really be at its best in a deck - a Draw-Go kind of deck - so it's odd that WotC didn't give this ability to a blue creature.

I guess Ronin Houndmaster has enslaved this little guy, given him a rusty sword and everything, but it's kind of interesting that if you manage to get "sevencraft", the goblin could take him in a fight!

84359: Michiko Konda, Truth Seeker.author: Pumpkin2146
84359: Michiko Konda, Truth Seeker.text_parsed:
DRCCOTD #3: Michiko Konda, Truth Seeker

Hmm, Michiko, I remember you well (for not really playing you very much at all). You obviously fail the vanilla test of any card, and you obviously did even in the weaker creature era in which you were printed. We expect much more from a than a 4CMC 2/2 unless you have a good ability. Thankfully for you Michiko, you DO have a good ability (at least some of the time). The question now really is, is your ability good ENOUGH, and if it is, is it good enough ENOUGH OF THE TIME.

Now this is possibly where you fall down. If your playing some kind of white based control deck against a white based weenie deck, and you resolve Michiko, your opponent might well have some trouble winning. They are going to have to lose a lot of permanents dealing damage to you, and are likely to have to choose between sacing weaker creatures and maintaining some ability to cast anything slightly expensive, or dumping the land and ignoring the higher CMC stuff in hand.

However, the problem is, we had to line up a lot of things for this to work, and even then, if you are playing a white based control deck, you almost certainly have cards like Wrath of God to handle swarms. In other matchups, Michiko doesn't really much. She was even downright horrible against commonly played cards from her block. Really doesn't look so good against Yosei, The Morning Star or Kokusho, The Evening Star now does she ?

One place she can shine though is multiplayer. She is a pretty good rattlesnake, she is good at deflecting attention from you to other players who will be less painful to attack, but without being so absurdly good that people decide she (or you) must die now !

84359: Michiko Konda, Truth Seeker.author: Asmodi0000
84359: Michiko Konda, Truth Seeker.text_parsed:
In multiplayer games, she's rather fiesty.

Despite only being a 2/2, she's my favorite blocker. She's the kind of blocker that can stop multiple creatures, even unblockable creatures, even if she's tapped or arrested or has lost the ability to block. She blocks with sheer presence.

She stops creatures from attacking you not because the creatures are strictly forbidden to, but because your opponents realize that there's far better targets for their advances in other directions. With a bit of advice from Michiko, they see that the real truth is they'd much prefer fighting amongst themselves, rather than involve you in their petty squabble.

After their resources are depleted and they're tired from their battle, is there any better moment to remind everyone that while Michiko is quite scary indeed, there is a far greater presence behind her?

84359: Michiko Konda, Truth Seeker.text_parsed:
Indestructibility, swiftfoot boots, whatever...

I dont think there is anything you can do with permanents to stop a big enough black sun's zenith, final judgment, or an overloaded cyclonic rift. There is no way to be assured this creature can stay on the battlefield, unless you have counterspells. Big removal will always remove irremovable threats, or else the game will become solitaire and both sides making irremovable you cant beat me cards like this and platinum angel.

However, you can prevent all "targeted" and even "destroy all" spells. But the above is impossible to stop unless you counter.

Just pointing it out, randomly.

84364: Kami of the Crescent Moon.author: jsttu
84364: Kami of the Crescent Moon.text_parsed:
This unassuming guy's name is Mochi, and he is the mastermind behind the entire Kamigawa plot. He inspired and helped Lord Konda steal from O-Kagachi, sparking the Kami war and devastating the populace. He is only defeated when Hidetsugu captures him and feeds him to the all consuming oni of chaos.

Mechanics wise, probably nice as card draw but his status as a creature and legendary both severely impair his usefulness. Temple Bell is probably better, although it would probably be a good EDH general for politics as everyone likes more cards and thus more options.

84364: Kami of the Crescent Moon.author: tommyb38
84364: Kami of the Crescent Moon.text_parsed: one of my favorite edh generals ever! probably the only general that's so non-threatening it never dies from spot removal too. i made him my general as a joke and put him in a mill style deck. the deck actually works most of the time and has a high win percentage. i highly recommend this guy as a general to anyone who's tired of losing a lot of edh games because players keep saying that their generals/decks are too good to play against so everyone gangs up on them first. you play something like this guy and players begin to overlook you and focus on bigger threats. this guy is very political in multiplayer games just like howling mine.

84364: Kami of the Crescent Moon.author: ParishInquisitor
84364: Kami of the Crescent Moon.text_parsed:
It's a decent creature with a nice ability; Howling Mine on a non-threatening body is great for negotiating in EDH. Nobody wants to kill the this guy, and having multiple "everyone draws" effects ensures that you make it to the late game.
Of course, when you have a mana-screwed opponent who doesn't appreciate having to discard all those extra cards, the kami becomes public enemy number one.
Still, a nice source for card draw.

Well worth the 6 mana casting cost.

84380: Celestial Kirin.author: Ender-A
84380: Celestial Kirin.text_parsed:
Remember: It only counts Spirit and Arcane spells! Also, don't forget the Changelings... and even better, the Changeling Spells. They count as Spirits. :)

There are three ways to destroy lands (and all other permanents with 0 CC) with it:
1) Cast Evermind. (Use Isochron Scepter, Kaho, Minamo Historian, cascade, etc. to get around the non-existent CC.)
2) Turn a 0-CC creature (i.e. Ornithopter, Memnite, Phyrexian Walker, Shield Sphere, Kobolds...; or Phyrexian Marauder, or Shifting Wall cast with X=0) into Spirit for when you cast it. Only way of turning creature spells into Spirits before you cast them that I know if is Conspiracy. You can't target them with Amoeboid Changeling, for example, because they aren't in play.
3) Change Celestial Kirin's rules text to specify a different creature type that matches a 0-CC spell: Artificial Evolution
84380: Celestial Kirin.text_posted:

1) Cast [autocard]Evermind[/autocard]. (Use [autocard]Isochron Scepter[/autocard], [autocard]Kaho, Minamo Historian[/autocard], cascade, etc. to get around the non-existent CC.)
2) Turn a 0-CC creature [i](i.e. [autocard]Ornithopter[/autocard], [autocard]Memnite[/autocard], [autocard]Phyrexian Walker[/autocard], [autocard]Shield Sphere[/autocard], Kobolds...; or [autocard]Phyrexian Marauder[/autocard], or [autocard]Shifting Wall[/autocard] cast with X=0)[/i] into Spirit for when you cast it. Only way of turning creature spells into Spirits [i]before you cast them[/i] that I know if is [autocard]Conspiracy[/autocard]. You [b]can't[/b] target them with [autocard]Amoeboid Changeling[/autocard], for example, because they aren't in play.

84639: Nikko-Onna.author: vantha
84639: Nikko-Onna.text_parsed:
Out of all the -onna cycle she is the most cost efficient and usable one. Its sad that someone from R&D didn't realize the potential of these cards and overcosted each one by 1 or 2 mana. They think that by playing an Arcane/Spirit spell that the reusability of these cards made them broken? Its pretty much Buyback for creatures. But you still have to make the initial investment plus you have to pay the spirit/Arcane spell also. And no, there were no 0 Casting cost Arcane or spirits, so over costing the -Onna cards was just bad decision making.
Here's the list if you want to compare them:
Haru-Onna
Yuki-Onna
Kiri-Onna
Kemuri-Onna
Niku-Onna

84705: Kemuri-Onna.author: Mode
84705: Kemuri-Onna.text_parsed:
To be honest, i would have been a lot happier with a Ravenous Rats take on her, even as a 0/1, especially because of the bounce all the Spirits from the Onna-cycle had.

Like this, you can barely make use of her second ability.
Who'd want to bounce a creature to cast her again for five mana for a meager discard effect?
On the other hand if this were a two-drop, i would gladly have bounced her a couple of times,
and Soulshifting her would have worked better as well... like, really good.

This could have made spirits more interesting, because many of Kamigawa's themes tended to be somewhat underpowered (and i do not mean this in comparison to Mirrodin's ridiculously broken standards,
but simply in only-non-banned-cards-are-allowed Standard standards).

84709: Blood Clock.author: Mode
84709: Blood Clock.text_parsed:
Apparently Umbilicus was urgently needed for Saviors of Kamigawa, yet the name didn't suit that nicely in the Set, so created a duplicate of that card, huh?

Even better - this way you have the choice to get this bounce up to eight times while stuffing your deck with cheap cip/etb-trigger owning cards. Unfortunately they might happen to use those cards as well, which doesn't happen that rarely. Sigh.
But if you prepare your deck with cards like Azorius Æthermage and others that profit from having many cards in hand (7+ cards on hand was the main themen in SoK after all), this could still find some good use.

Both cards - or at least this remake - could have used a cheaper mana cost, though.

84711: Inner Fire.author: Mode
84711: Inner Fire.text_parsed:
I agree, even for Seething Song will do a better, more reliable job most of the time, and for it would be too powerful again.
Mana accel based on the cards in hand is apparently hard to make both useful and balanced.
The same is true if they made this a cantrip - if it let you draw a card it would provide free mana accel (and would increase the Storm spells count), yet for this would be easy to achieve. Yet for this would get tricky again...

I think they should have either reduced the cost to or made this spell: "Add to your mana pool, then add to your mana pool for each card in your hand." This way you would need 5 cards in hand to make better use of it than Seething Song, and it could still become useful in a deck with heavy card advantage.
84711: Inner Fire.text_posted:
I agree, even for [2R] [autocard]Seething Song[/autocard] will do a better, more reliable job most of the time, and for [1R] it would be too powerful again.
Mana accel based on the cards in hand is apparently hard to make both useful and balanced.
The same is true if they made this a cantrip - if it let you draw a card it would provide free mana accel (and would increase the Storm spells count), yet for [3R] this would be easy to achieve. Yet for [4R] this would get tricky again...

I think they should have either reduced the cost to [2R] or made this spell: "[i]Add [RR] to your mana pool, then add [R] to your mana pool for each card in your hand.[/i]" This way you would need 5 cards in hand to make better use of it than Seething Song, and it could still become useful in a deck with heavy card advantage.

84711: Inner Fire.author: RowanKeltizar
84711: Inner Fire.text_parsed:
Granted it's useless in anything but a U/R deck with a ton of draw but it really excels in that particular deck. Personally, I love it. It's an undiscovered gem for Niv-Mizzet, The Firemind EDH decks.

Reiterate + Inner Fire + 7 cards in hand (not counting reiterate) + 7RRR = infinite red mana. You can then use the bought back reiterate to reiterate pretty much any other spell for infinite damage or removal (infinite Chaos Warps or Brainstorms is fun) Or just pour it into a Comet Storm or Conflagrate.

I do this usually by turn 4-7 on average but turn 1 is possible with certain broken blue cards which shall not be named) Barring those, Consecrated Sphinx + Wheel of Fortune works quite nicely.

Whenever I use it to get like 10 to 50 red mana I smirk as people "ooh" and "aww" because then I just reiterate or twincast it for much much more. How much more "Firemind" can you get?? With this strategy, Niv has become sort of a backup. He just watches it go down without actually doing any work. Lazy dragon.

5/5 for it's roll in my combo EDH deck

84712: Yuki-Onna.author: vantha
84712: Yuki-Onna.text_parsed:
I pay close attention to Japanese myth and legend and I was surprised that Yuki-Onna ended up being Red. but from a story perspective she was a cold hearted vengeful spirit, I guess thats her red aspect. the ability to destroy artifacts repeatedly wasn't too much of a concern back in Kamigawa. The cast of 4 mana after bouncing her was a bit steep, considering what Arcane and spirit spells were available at the time.

84716: Homura, Human Ascendant // Homura.author: FurnaceOfRath
84716: Homura, Human Ascendant // Homura.text_parsed:
Under the new Legendary rule, you should be able to flip this guy just by playing a second one, and you should be able to keep both copies of it.
Lets say you have one on the battlefield and then play a second one. The new legend rule will force you to pick one and send the other to the graveyard as a state based effect. The one that went to the grave should then return flipped as per its ability. You then have one Homura, Human Ascendant and one Homura's Essence, and, since they have different names now, the legend rule should not apply.

84716: Homura, Human Ascendant // Homura.author: Marve5
84716: Homura, Human Ascendant // Homura.text_parsed: I have a blast playing this guy as my mono-red EDH Commander - he unleashes the dragon in everything! But I do know that he can't do it alone, so he gets ramp and fatties for all that Firebreathing. He also thrives in a deck with enough synergy to kill him, since opponents are likely going to try and keep him alive. There are the obvious deck choices...Crater Hellion, Flametongue Kavu, Ryusei, the Falling Star, and then there are the less obvious choices Warstorm Surge, Butcher Orgg, Grab the Reins. Oh, and he does love sweepers. Those sweet, sweet red sweepers... Star Storm, Blasphemous Act.

87330: Murmurs from Beyond.author: DoctorKenneth
87330: Murmurs from Beyond.text_parsed:
@McThor:
And when my Emrakul shuffles back in, I'll thank you for the Instant-speed, arcane Divination.

Though to be fair, this isn't something you'd run outside a deck that's mostly blue. The instant speed really helps it, obviously, as that precious counterspell mana is open. But nine times out of ten, you'll want some straight-up instant card draw. The exception is when you're pulling some shenannegins with the Arcane mechaninc, and even then there are better Arcane spells to be doing that with. Also, Arcane wasn't really super-popular.

Of course, ten times out of ten, you'll be wanting to use it's big brother, Fact or Fiction. So don't get me wrong. This isn't exactly good. Hell, even Truth or Tale is preferable, as it leaves you with considerably more options. And having options is good.

87330: Murmurs from Beyond.text_parsed: It gets beat out by the almighty fact or fiction. Still, not bad.
87330: Murmurs from Beyond.text_posted: It gets beat out by the almighty [autocard]fact or fiction[/autocard]. Still, not bad.

87330: Murmurs from Beyond.author: Edward_Mass
87330: Murmurs from Beyond.text_parsed:
It's not Fact or Fiction (FoF). It'll never be Fact or Fiction. And, as Wizards has already made clear, they're committed to keeping Fact or Fiction out of Standard and Modern. So, let's just drop it already.

Now, with that out of the way, let's actually review the card, shall we? It's really pretty sweet.

An instant-speed Divination-like spell with only two real drawbacks: You reveal the cards (big, but not a deal breaker); your opponent denies you one of them (minor, despite what some claim). I'll repeat that. Your opponent denying you ONE CARD out of three is LESS IMPORTANT than them seeing all three cards in the first place.

I'd go so far as to say that Murmurs is strong enough, as a card, to warrant a rarity bump if it were every reprinted (and I despise rarity bumps in practice). The only reason it's not rated higher is that it's outclassed by its big sister, Gifts Ungiven.

And let's remember that Gifts Ungiven is a boss in every format where it's legal. Let's remember that old FoF we were just talking about. In both cases, your opponent has influence over what you get. Hell, Gifts let's them choose outright. Yet both those cards are all-stars.

So, the huge drawback people are worried about is really nothing. And comparing this unfavorably to Truth or Tale? That mess of a card? DoctorK, are you high? I'll take two cards over 1 any day, especially if I'm spending 2+ mana on the spell. Truth or Tale is, ultimately, just a bad cantrip. The options mean nothing and the selection process is poorly worded as well as being unnecessarily drawn out.

4/5

87330: Murmurs from Beyond.author: Mode
87330: Murmurs from Beyond.text_parsed:
It's Instant Speed and an Arcane, two reasons that make it worth to consider playing instead of Counsel of the Soratami (which is this block's, and the original Divination).
Still, out of the three cards, your opponent will get rid of the biggest threat.
Unless your deck heavily utilizes the graveyard (for example if you have cards with (cheap) Flashback), in which case it's often win/win for you either way and your opponent might just pick a land card.

87331: Molting Skin.author: allmighty_abacus
87331: Molting Skin.text_parsed:
The mechanic isn't that great- noncreature cards that do nothing but provide a regeneration trigger are overrated especially since most removal nowadays is focused on exiling creatures (ie path of exile, journey to nowhere, O-ring etc).

But I personally preferred the art from broken fall. It made since, flavor-wise. Gerrard gets knocked out of a tree and falls on a pile of leaves, breaking his fall. What happens here on this card? Snake people taught humans how to shed skin? How can one teach that? And even if you could, how would that negate getting a sword plunged in to your chest? Or a fireball roasting your flesh? GG Kamigawa, you done f.ucked up a harmless card.

87332: Dosan's Oldest Chant.author: OpenSeasonNoobs
87332: Dosan's Oldest Chant.text_parsed: It's a cheaper version of Kiss of the Amesha and it's single color. It's not a bad card for limited by any means. Just because it's not Jund or Vamps doesn't mean it's bad. And just because Harmonize was good doesn't mean any other green draw is bad. Learn to combo, green draw is always good, and draw + gain life is great to have in a single card. Use it in a G/W life gain with Sanguine Bond. Gives you potential 6 loss of life and negates the fact that it's in your deck. Sure, Survival Cache is better, but you have to cast it twice and it's not all at once AND... the kicker... It's white, not green. High cost in green is laughable, 5 mana is nothing. You can easily get 5 open mana turn 3 in a green deck. turn 1, Search for Tomorrow, turn 2 Rampant Growth turn 3 your search goes off and you drop your 5th. Easily 6 life and a draw at that point which you'll be needing to draw past your ramp. It fits green VERY well. You know... Unless Pelakka Wurm is bad because it costs 7....

87332: Dosan's Oldest Chant.text_parsed:
"Easily 6 life and a draw at that point which you'll be needing to draw past your ramp. It fits green VERY well. You know... Unless Pelakka Wurm is bad because it costs 7.... "
Pelakka Wurm is great because it's a 7/7 trampling creature, and the life gain and card are just icing. If this card were equally as worthwhile as Pelakka Wurm, then you're saying that a 7/7 trampling wurm should cost GG. And since Duskdale Wurm costs 5GG and NOT GG, we see that Dosan's Oldest Chant is utter junk.

If you're going to ramp into 5 mana on turn three, you're better off playing Kodama of the North Tree or a common Stomper Cub. Heck, even playing Yavimaya Elder and leaving two lands untapped would be better.

-- HairlessThoctar

Pretty sure they knew about this during Kamigawa cycle already.
Compare it with Sunbeam Spellbomb or Nourish for example, which came one cycle earlier.

It's just one of their needlessly overcosted cards they feel like printing every now and then.
This could easily have been cheaper, an instant, or even both. Compare it to Reviving Dose.

Life gain cantrips can be pretty useful actually, especially at instant speed.
Renewed Faith for example has great versatility.

I'd still play Dosan's Oldest Chant over Blessed Wine, Bargain and Rejuvenate, though.

That said, it sursprisingly seems to be the only green life gain cantrip so far.

A cheap Conspiracy just for your graveyard.
JWolps is likely right regarding the Soulshift keyword considering that Spirits were the biggest tribal type of the Kamigawa Cycle.
It does an even better job with Haakon, Stromgald Scourge though, since it lets you cast creatures from your graveyard to get them directly onto your battlefield, not just on your hand after the right Spiritcreature died as it would be with Soulshift.
What a pity this artifact didn't just cost or was made a cantrip regarding the pretty weak actual intention this card had.

87336: Freed from the Real.author: Donovan_Fabian
87336: Freed from the Real.text_parsed: This card has a lot of potential for craziness, but after playing one in my own deck I also realized its sort of limited, you have to have a creature in play with a tap you want to use multiple times and the blue mana to do it.  At worst its sort of like giving a creature vigilance, at best you can reuse somethings tap ability several times which can be very powerful.  In all the games I've played with it so far I've only got real use out of it twice though.  It is infamous for its infinite mana combos, bloom tender being one, and sachi, orochi leaf caller, together being another.  I don't use infinite mana engines though, they aren't fun in my opinion, and they aren't fun for your opponent either, and I don't want to play a card if I'm not having fun doing it.  If you simply want the untap instill energy allows you to do it for free but only once a turn.

87336: Freed from the Real.author: DarthKithkin
87336: Freed from the Real.text_parsed:
303.4e An Aura’s controller is separate from the enchanted object’s controller; the two need not be the same. Changing control of the object doesn’t change control of the Aura, and vice versa. Only the Aura’s controller can activate its abilities. However, if the Aura grants an ability to the enchanted object (with “gains” or “has”), the enchanted object’s controller is the only one who can activate that ability.

Can anyone explain this?
87336: Freed from the Real.text_posted:
303.4e An Aura’s controller is separate from the enchanted object’s controller; the two need not be the same. Changing control of the object doesn’t change control of the Aura, and vice versa. Only the Aura’s controller can activate its abilities. However, if the Aura grants an ability to the enchanted object (with “gains” or “has”), the enchanted object’s controller is the only one who can activate that ability. 

Can anyone explain this?

87336: Freed from the Real.author: holgir
87336: Freed from the Real.text_parsed:
@DarthKithkin:

You have a Fugitive Wizard enchanted with Freed from the Real and Quicksilver Dagger.
If an opponent gains control of your creature with Act of Treason, he can use the ability of the Dagger because it is "granted" to the creature ("Enchanted creature has..."). He can't use Freed from the Real because its ability is not depending on control of the enchanted creature. You still control both auras though.

Hmm... I've recently been on the hunt for creatures that double as makeshift instants and sorceries. Little did I expect to find the Ghost-lit cycle back in Kamigawa as well as the channel mechanic. I simply adore the design for these cards, tattered cloaks, Master Splicer-esk hats and... Well... Lanterns. Oh how I love lanterns.

Right, the card itself. Raider's the one I find most compelling. For a creature heavy deck, removal tends to be light. So, 3 mana to ping things for 2 or 4 mana to just flame slash something. It's at least worth a look.

87593: Eternal Dominion.author: Synnestro
87593: Eternal Dominion.text_parsed:
I'm thinking of using this card in a blue control deck. Basically, my opponent would be on complete lock down with cards like Mist of Stagnation, Orb of Dreams, Precognition, and Arcane Laboratory...meanwhile, I'd also have Think Tank and Paradox Haze in play to ensure that I'm the one getting the most out of each turn. I figure if you throw this into the mix, after placing down all the cards mentioned above, I'd get to play any of my opponents cards for free each turn while they struggle to play just one of theirs.

Now, I might know what you're thinking...with Orb of Dreams the permanent would come into play tapped but, if I also have Murkfiend Liege in play or perhaps Merrow Commerce (with merfolk creatures of course), all of my creatures would untap while my opponent is left untapping permanents based on their graveyard.

The only problem I've been running into while making this deck is this...what kinds of creatures should I use? So far I've decided on Djinn of Wishes and Sphinx of Jwar Isle (both together would ensure I get the best choices out of Djinn's ability) but I'm not sure what or who else to add...Chronozoa maybe?

87593: Eternal Dominion.author: MacBizzle
87593: Eternal Dominion.text_parsed:
MULTIPLE EPIC SPELLS ARE FEASIBLE TO SET OFF. You need two in your hand (two of the same would work); a quicken, vedalken orrery, or leyline of anticipation; and ridiculous amounts of mana production (such as Cloudpost, Glimmerpost, Vesuva and Mycosynth Lattice) or mana reduction (such as the Planeshift familiars or Cloudkey).

Slap down one Epic spell, then before it resolves, quicken, then put another Epic spell on the stack. By the time one resolves, the other one's already been cast, and is not affected by "You can't cast spells". This has been confirmed by a MTG customer support representative via email..

Just by itself this might turn out to be more of an epic fail than an epic win, at least if you cast it in the late game and play against decks for instance that don't run costy permanents.

I'd certainly play this with manlands like Mishra's Factory or Celestial Colonnade, and various permanents like Panoptic Mirror with abilities that let me circumvent the fail part of this epic spell.

This could also be a nice target for Spellweaver Helix to cast it early (via cards like Intuition and Raven's Crime).

87593: Eternal Dominion.author: ProbablyThatGuy
87593: Eternal Dominion.text_parsed:
Multiplayer blue mage's wet dream for sure. Very risky, for not an overwhelming benefit in relation to its mana cost, but incredibly fun. Even the picture screams epic spell. This is never ever coming out of my mono-blue EDH.

@BlueInkAlchemist
Yes, since you aren't casting/playing the copies, you are putting additional copies of the spell onto the stack, as stated in Echo Mage's rulings. So yes, you can indeed copy the spell 2 times over on each of your successive turns with a leveled up mage, building up more and more copies of it. Another cool choice is Uyo, Silent Prophet, to get a whole bunch on stack as soon as possible, before your replicating source is destroyed. Also, you can still replay those lands you bounce since lands are not spells.

87594: Endless Swarm.author: DeathDark
87594: Endless Swarm.text_parsed:
This is potentially more epic than it sounds. All you need are:

Spellbook and/or Reliquary Tower
Some number of Howling Mines
Coat of Arms

So, potentially, first turn you play it, and let's say you're at 7 in your hand. You now have 7 7/7 Snakes.
Next turn, you get 7 more, so you have 14 14/14 snakes. Then you draw 5.
Next turn, you get 12 more, so you have 26 26/26 snakes.

You see where I'm going with this.

87594: Endless Swarm.author: MacBizzle
87594: Endless Swarm.text_parsed:
MULTIPLE EPIC SPELLS ARE FEASIBLE TO SET OFF. You need two in your hand (two of the same would work); a quicken, vedalken orrery, or leyline of anticipation; and ridiculous amounts of mana production (such as Cloudpost, Glimmerpost, Vesuva and Mycosynth Lattice) or mana reduction (such as the Planeshift familiars or Cloudkey).

Slap down one Epic spell, then before it resolves, quicken, then put another Epic spell on the stack. By the time one resolves, the other one's already been cast, and is not affected by "You can't cast spells". This has been confirmed by a MTG customer support representative via email.
87594: Endless Swarm.text_posted:
MULTIPLE EPIC SPELLS ARE FEASIBLE TO SET OFF. Slap down one Epic spell, then before it resolves, quicken, then put another Epic spell on the stack. By the time one resolves, the other one's already been cast, and is not affected by "You can't cast spells". This has been confirmed by a MTG customer support representative via email.

87594: Endless Swarm.author: DazeRyuken
87594: Endless Swarm.text_parsed: @TomYoung : Angelic Arbiter wouldn't stop your friend from attacking. The Epic keyword ability copies the spell directly onto the stack, without any casting involved. It keeps things from getting confusing since Epic prevents you from actually casting anything, period. In this case, the Arbiter's ability wouldn't be able to stop your friend's horde of snakes from attacking.

87594: Endless Swarm.author: Kelptic183
87594: Endless Swarm.text_parsed:
It's probably a good idea to throw down an Eldrazi Monument before you cast this thing. It's also important to note that you can copy this spell while it's on the stack to get multiple instances of the epic ability during each upkeep. You can also copy the epic copies with activated abilities like Mirari or Nivix Guildmage to get an extra spell, although those copies won't have epic.

Hint: if you want to copy epic spells, few people are better than Riku of Two Reflections.

87595: Sasaya, Orochi Ascendant // Sasay.author: VoidedNote
87595: Sasaya, Orochi Ascendant // Sasay.text_parsed:
My only question is... who the hell is going to have 7 lands in their hand... ever?

Powerful ability, but... nobody will pull it off with an sort of regularity. I've seen less farfetched 5 card combo's than trying to flip this thing. Besides, you can make a far more powerful combo deck than anything this could pull off. In fact, there are cards that do this one's job just as well. And considering this was back when mana burn was still alive (and before Zendikar), this was usually suicide if you didn't have a random X spell in your hand. And really the only kind that would help would be a burn spell, because not many kamigawa cards with X in them need a rediculous amount of mana. Overall, not worth the effort.

The creature is subpar too, 2/3 for 3? No thanks, I'll go with something decent.

1/5

87595: Sasaya, Orochi Ascendant // Sasay.author: MagicalHacker
87595: Sasaya, Orochi Ascendant // Sasay.text_parsed:
I'm surprised more people haven't broken this guy already!

If you play 90ish lands, 10 mana dump cards, and this guy as the general, you can flip him every game at turn 4 if you keep 6 lands and a mana dump card in your hand.

I personally like Nemata, Grove Guardian the best because you only make three saprolings on turn 4, but turn five, after you swing with them, make 8 more saprolings and sac them all to give each saproling +8/+8. So you're taking all that 31 damage (4 from the Nemata) since you said no blocks, right?

Obviously though, Blightsteel Colossus wins faster.

87596: Kuon, Ogre Ascendant // Kuon's Es.author: rubber
87596: Kuon, Ogre Ascendant // Kuon's Es.text_parsed:
When 3 creatures die in a turn, you turn it upside down and its other text becomes its abilities.

Reminiscent of The Abyss. I would think this card would be great for a deck full of sweepers, but if he dies too that's useless. He does survive Infest.

87596: Kuon, Ogre Ascendant // Kuon's Es.author: Mode
87596: Kuon, Ogre Ascendant // Kuon's Es.text_parsed:
The requirement for the trigger simply don't work that nicely with the flipped effect.

The Abyss is that good because it simply means Diabolic Edict for your opponent each turn once it's cast without you being required to do anything else but not running (non-artifact) creatures.

But by the time you manage to get three creatures into the graveyard in a single turn, you either did so with creatures on your side, which means that this effect will cost you creatures as well, or you won't need that effect any longer since you already hosed the battlefield anyways.

It can still find some use though with recurring creatures like Bloodghast, Nether Traitor, or Myr Servitor.

Unfortunately the mana cost of this guy really asks for using this in a mono-colored deck.

87598: Enduring Ideal.author: beyurslf
87598: Enduring Ideal.text_parsed:
Enduring Ideal can't combo with Mirror Sheen. It does not target anything.
A card like Yavimaya Enchantress is great with this deck if you have Enchanted Evening in it. Ancestral Mask is also a great addition.
Before playing the epic card, when you have Enchanted Evening out, try Wrap in Vigor and then Tranquility or Leave No Trace.

87598: Enduring Ideal.author: brunsbr103
87598: Enduring Ideal.text_parsed:
This is so fun to combo with hive mind, if you can get it out your opponent will have to deal with the Epic ability too! to make things more fun use an Enchanted Evening and an Aura Fracture to have complete control over your opponent. It's not like you'll be using too many lands after the epic ability resolves, and if you need more enchanted evening lets you fetch them whenever you need them!

The only bad parts about this card is it's high mana cost and that you need to build your deck around it to use it well...

I had mirror sheen in the comments before, appologies for a faulty combo.

87598: Enduring Ideal.author: CrazyCombatCarl
87598: Enduring Ideal.text_parsed: Okay this would be awesome as the core to an all enchantment deck. About 45 cards in size running 4 of these. First priorty is to cast this as fast as possible, I recomand Dark Ritual and Remote Farm. Mulligan to make sure you have a good start hand. Then first thing you search is forSterling Grove. Turn two of Epic pull out a second Sterling Grove. 3: get Everlasting Torment. 4: pull out Transcendence at this point you can't die except by deck fliping or by a card that destroys all enchantments in play. 5: VERY IMPORANT Dragon Appeasement after all you can't play spells so haveing enchanments in hand aren't going to help you anymore. 6,7,8,9: pull out your 4 copies of Necra Sanctuary for the win. If you want run other fun enchanments in mass like Hondens. Just make sure you have 4copies of your early enchaments incase you accidently start with them in your start hand. Crazy set of plays that usually leave your opponent jaw dropped also goood for a few loughs.

87598: Enduring Ideal.author: MacBizzle
87598: Enduring Ideal.text_parsed:
MULTIPLE EPIC SPELLS ARE FEASIBLE TO SET OFF. You need two in your hand (two of the same would work); a quicken, vedalken orrery, or leyline of anticipation; and ridiculous amounts of mana production (such as Cloudpost, Glimmerpost, Vesuva and Mycosynth Lattice) or mana reduction (such as the Planeshift familiars or Cloudkey).

Slap down one Epic spell, then before it resolves, quicken, then put another Epic spell on the stack. By the time one resolves, the other one's already been cast, and is not affected by "You can't cast spells". This has been confirmed by a MTG customer support representative via email.

"Haha, you can't play any more spells this game? That's a terrible card!"
*Ideal searches up Form of the Dragon, then Mystic Decree*
"...good game."
More likely, they won't just say "good game", they'll say "Lava Axe targeting you... good game"

And what's with everyone giving love to Enchanted Evening? Why the heck do you care that permanents are enchantments? Doesn't do anything for Ideal.

As for you people with a blanket rule of "First turn always pull...Sterling Grove, Dovescape, etc."... There is no rule about your first turn except that on the first turn, you react to what's on the board and make sure you get a second turn. That could mean an Oblivion Ring or a Faith's Fetters or Meishin, the Mind Cage. Then probably a Zur's Weirding so you can see your opponent's hand and make sure they can't kill you when you pull Form of the Dragon.

Seriously, I wonder if any of you ever played an Ideal deck before with your card selection and "rules" about what you grab first.

87598: Enduring Ideal.author: WarioMan
87598: Enduring Ideal.text_parsed: Now that we have the ten (and soon fifteen) Gods of Theros, this card became the centerpiece for my WUBRG Child of Alara/Progenitus EDH deck. You can use Form of the Dragon and Phyrexian Unlife to make sure you can't lose, toss out a bunch of Shroud-giving stuff like Greater Auramancy and such, and then lastly grab things such as Propaganda for that last layer of protection. By the way, use Island Sanctuary to stop drawing cards. Once you start grabbing gods, it's all downhill from there. Aside from having a TON of enchantments on the board, if all 15 gods are on the battlefield, they provide enough devotion to animate each other so you can LITERALLY unleash the power of all the Gods at once on your poor victim.

87598: Enduring Ideal.author: kor6sic6
87598: Enduring Ideal.text_parsed:
I'm mainly an EDH player, and I've put together a deck list with 41 enchantments to make this card go crazy. Obvious inclusions, Paradox Haze for double the pleasure, Form of the Dragon, Dovescape and Phyrexian Unlife to never die, and a bunch of other cheeky pieces as well. My win-con is Eidolon of Countless Battles from Born of the Gods, slapped with an Ethereal Armor and Daybreak Coronet.
Some of the cheeky enchantments are auras that steal permanents. There are also a bunch of non-enchantment pieces to help fish out pieces I need; tutors and creatures like Academy Rector.
I'm excited to get all the pieces together and test it out.

87599: Erayo, Soratami Ascendant // Eray.author: KillerWhiskey
87599: Erayo, Soratami Ascendant // Eray.text_parsed:
If the third spell was played, Erayo is on the battlefield, and someone tries to Shock him, that would count as a fourth spell and his trigger would go off and resolve before Shock resolves. The burn spell would then have no legal targets and fizzle as a result.

If Erayo himself is the fourth spell, the trigger doesn't go off as he isn't on the battlefield. Someone might even cast a fourth spell while he's on the stack and prevent him from flipping.

Some decks actually do have combos that feature Erayo and another card, like Mana Maze or Arcane Laboratory, and are able to do a second-turn flip (as showcased by Ruins). I'm certain that Vintage decks could even do a turn 1 flip - Mox/Mox/Erayo/Mox, but that's hardly effective as most Vintage decks run even more restraining cards like Trinisphere.

If you're running combo with him, definitely use cards like Cloud of Faeries or Snap. Lotus Petal is good, but if you're running a right type of a deck, Gustha's Scepter might also come in handy.

If you're running casual, either go with the suspend mechanic or instants - play them during your opponents turn and make him help you out getting that fourth spell.

The card by itself is pure brilliance. Never before have I seen an effect with so much potential for only two mana.

Definitely a 5/5.

87599: Erayo, Soratami Ascendant // Eray.author: Atali
87599: Erayo, Soratami Ascendant // Eray.text_parsed: There is no such thing as an unbeatable combo, but Erayo + Arcane Lab is one of the hardest locks in existence, and if you're going to build a deck to set it up, you are probably going to think ahead and put things in it to make its few cracks even harder to exploit. Time Stop can counter an uncounterable spell, as can Mindbreak Trap, you can Annex Boseiju, or just play it yourself so you can destroy it if your opponent tries to use it.

For the question "Can you recur erayo with Hanna, Ship's Navigator?" from xDrSnuggles:

No.

709.2. In every zone other than the battlefield, and also on the battlefield before the permanent flips, a flip card has only the normal characteristics of the card. Once a permanent is flipped, its normal name, text box, type line, power, and toughness don't apply and the alternative versions of those characteristics apply instead.

87600: Rune-Tail, Kitsune Ascendant // R.author: divinewind08
87600: Rune-Tail, Kitsune Ascendant // R.text_parsed: I've seen people commenting about this guy in EDH, and I wanted to give my thoughts. I don't think that this card should be outright banned in EDH. Unless you are lucky, this thing will have a hard time flipping, by the time you draw it. However, I DO think it should be banned as a General. The fact that you will be able to drop this guy and flip him on turn three almost every game is absurd. Even if your opponent is able to destroy him, you can pay 5 and bring him right back. By the time your opponent is able to fetch up more removal, you will have had plenty of time to get the mana to cast him again at his increased cost. All it takes is a hand full of creatures and/or some kind of catch all (like Pariah), and creatures can't touch you. This is probably the second most unfair General that is currently legal. The first spot goes to Zur the Enchanter.

87600: Rune-Tail, Kitsune Ascendant // R.author: strider24seven
87600: Rune-Tail, Kitsune Ascendant // R.text_parsed:
To all those complaining about how "unfair" this card is in EDH:

Rune-Tail only prevents damage to creatures.

1. He does not prevent creature removal
2. He does not provide any sort of protection to himself and dies to removal
3. He does not help against creatures with trample
4. He does not prevent damage to you
5. He does not prevent loss of life
6. He does not prevent death via mill
7. He does not prevent other "lose the game" effects

That said, he is a strong protective effect that will likely allow you to establish a better board presence. If enchantment removal were not so cheap and accessible to every choice of colours except mono-black, mono-red, and Rakdos colours, then this would be a much stronger effect.

Search gatherer for Rules Text: "Destroy Enchantment" and "Destroy Permanent" and sort by descending community rating. That's how easy it is to remove Rune-Tail in EDH.

Many (if not most) win conditions also bypass Rune-Tail, such as Tendrils of Agony, Exsanguinate, Helm of Obedience, Blue Sun's Zenith, Craterhoof Behemoth, Triumph of the Hordes... and the list goes on.

Here's a list of some common EDH archetypes that Rune-Tail has minimal effect on:
1. Mill (ignores Rune-Tail and mills you out)
2. Storm (ignores Rune-Tail and combos out)
3. Tokens (prevents some early free damage, then overruns and ignores Rune-Tail, or ignores Rune-Tail and combos out)
4. Control (prevents Lightning Bolt-esque removal, otherwise removes Rune-Tail and continues controlling)
5. Non-Token Overrun (prevents some early free damage then overruns and ignores Rune-Tail)
6. Big-Mana Combo (ignores Rune-Tail and combos out)
7. Blue Aggro (plays evasive dudes and ignores Rune-Tail)

Here's a list of the archetypes that Rune-Tail has a slight dampening effect on:
1. Non-Blue Aggro
2. Burn (not an effective archetype, but there you go)

Here's a list of the archetypes that Rune-Tail is truly oppressive against:
(null)

For those comparing him to Erayo, Erayo is actually oppressive. With Arcane Laboratory (or simply a healthy supply of counter-magic), no player other than the one controlling Erayo and those running and have drawn Vexing Shusher can cast spells after turn three or four.

See my post on Serra Ascendant about why strong plays in EDH should not be banned. The TL;DR is:

If you're deck can't handle (insert strong card here), then your deck is not a strong deck. Don't blame the card... build a better deck.

Neverending Torment - Cost 5

1 - Spellbook and a land
2 - Another land, and a Howling Mine
3 - Another land, and another Howling Mine
4 - Another land, another Howling Mine, and perhaps a defender of some sort (Drudge Skeletons)
5 - This card

87601: Neverending Torment.author: MacBizzle
87601: Neverending Torment.text_parsed:
MULTIPLE EPIC SPELLS ARE FEASIBLE TO SET OFF. You need two in your hand (two of the same would work); a quicken, vedalken orrery, or leyline of anticipation; and ridiculous amounts of mana production (such as Cloudpost, Glimmerpost, Vesuva and Mycosynth Lattice) or mana reduction (such as the Planeshift familiars or Cloudkey).

Slap down one Epic spell, then before it resolves, quicken, then put another Epic spell on the stack. By the time one resolves, the other one's already been cast, and is not affected by "You can't cast spells". This has been confirmed by a MTG customer support representative via email.

Also, @DeathDark: Neverending Torment costs 6, brah. C'mon, don't be lazy, the cost is right here on this page.

87602: Undying Flames.author: Mr_Hendry
87602: Undying Flames.text_parsed: This not exactly a Goblin Charbelcher. The converted mana cost aspect is quite different than simple summed nonlands. You have more potential for damage with this card on average, especially if you're stocked with fatties and other costly spells. The beauty of this spell is it's continuity. Yes, all consuming continuity but continuity nonetheless. I would never venture to claim it's strictly better than Goblin Charbelcher but it may be. At the very least this card is more gratifying because you translate not order drawn but mana cost into damage.

87602: Undying Flames.author: DarthParallax
87602: Undying Flames.text_parsed:
Wizards hadn't really embraced remembering Multiplayer while Designing Kamigawa block.

Not just 'because I can', but also because it's actually quite natural to do so, if I were a Designer today making a new Cycle of Epic cards, I would definitely have the Red one Hit Everything Forever. This is a fantastic card to apply "Overload logic" to.

Eternal Destruction: 5RRR

Sorcery

Exile cards from the top of your library until you reveal a nonland card. Eternal Destruction deals damage to each creature and planeswalker equal to twice the converted mana cost of that card.
Epic.

Of course, this card on it's own could not win any games, but I'm positive deck brewers would immediately find solace in the right kinds of Black enchantment cards to make sure they can 'finish the job', and I think an Epic spell doesn't have to win the game by itself to be cool. In fact I think this one would be improved if it were forced to rely on synergies to work, in exchange for having more high end potential :) I mean jeez, imagine how much life you could gain if you found the right White Enchantment while we're at it. :P

87602: Undying Flames.author: blurrymadness
87602: Undying Flames.text_parsed:
I honestly think all of the Epic spells could've just copied the Epic ability anyway. They *should* be nigh-guaranteed finishers. Afterall, a simple counterspell every turn (quite achievable *even within the block*) shuts it down and you can't do anything.

They tend to be only somewhat fun as you as a player have basically exited the game. What makes a game fun is a series of interesting choices and these take choice away from the player. Therefore, the effect should be as huge as possible to keep it entertaining and end the game (or lack of game) quickly. The epic instead allows the player a *single action* every turn, out of their control, and this one could easily hit for 1-3 damage even in a deck based around 6-10 mana cost cards.

Maybe I'm being somewhat unfair as you could have creatures with various activated abilities and such; you could combo next to AEther Vial or similar; but it just seems painfully "meh" when you spend loads on a spell. This isn't the worst offender given it's only 6 mana, but I don't think it's unreasonable to see a spell crescendo out of this.

I mean..

they've printed *storm* cards. These adding a quadratic number of spells each turn would hardly be the thing that breaks the game.
87602: Undying Flames.text_posted:
I honestly think all of the Epic spells could've just copied the Epic ability anyway. They *should* be nigh-guaranteed finishers. Afterall, a simple [autocard]counterspell[/autocard] every turn (quite achievable *even within the block*) shuts it down and you can't do anything. 

They tend to be only somewhat fun as you as a player have basically exited the game.  What makes a game fun is a series of interesting choices and these take choice away from the player. Therefore, the effect should be as huge as possible to keep it entertaining and end the game (or lack of game) quickly. The epic instead allows the player a *single action* every turn, out of their control, and this one could easily hit for 1-3 damage even in a deck based around 6-10 mana cost cards.

Maybe I'm being somewhat unfair as you could have creatures with various activated abilities and such; you could combo next to [autocard]AEther Vial[/autocard] or similar; but it just seems painfully "meh" when you spend loads on a spell. This isn't the worst offender given it's only 6 mana, but I don't think it's unreasonable to see a spell crescendo out of this.

I mean..

they've printed *[i]storm[/i]* cards. These adding a quadratic number of spells each turn would hardly be the thing that breaks the game.

88784: Oboro Breezecaller.author: Kamishini
88784: Oboro Breezecaller.text_parsed:
Okay! So I thought of an infinite mana any color combo with this card, Patron of the Moon, Lotus Vale, and two other lands on the field that don't bounce other land.

Step 1: Tap Lotsu Vale for three {W} {U} {B} {R} {G}.
Step 2: Pay {2} to bounce misc. land with Oboro Breezecaller's ability. Untap Lotus Vale. One floating mana of the color tapped with Lotus Vale.
Step 3: Repeat Step 1 than 2. Two mana floating of any color.
Step 4: Pay {1} to place the two land you bounced into play with Patron of the Moon's ability. One mana of any color you choose left floating.
Step 5: Repeat Steps 1 through 4 for infinite mana of any color combination!

Yay! I think I semi-redeemed this card, with it's absolutely GORGEOUS artwork!

Sorry for any formatting issues, and I'm sure someone else has though of this before, but I didn't see it posted up here so... And I know it's fragile, but hey! Who's gonna suspect this is part of an infinite mana combo?

88784: Oboro Breezecaller.author: Tzaph
88784: Oboro Breezecaller.text_parsed:
I used to run this lady in a janky casual RUG deck. I'd get down a Krosan Tusker or Tangle Golem, load a land up with several Dawn's Reflection, then use the Breezecaller to generate lots of mana by untapping the buffed land multiple times. All the while, my other lands would go back to my hand, and I'd spend the mana on multiple Rush of Knowledge to find my win condition; Spiraling Embers.
What I'm saying is that even a fairly lacklustre card can find a piece in a fun, casual combo deck!

Considering how even among Auras, those that don't target creatures are even rarer then Auras already are, running Unsummon (or Consuming Vortex, if you care for Arcanes) is a better alternative in most cases.

Now if it gave you the option to return the auras attached the targeted permanent as well,
this would at least make a nice Rescue for your enchanted permanents.

Come to think of it, your suggestion of making it a cantrip would have also worked in that manner, since that would have kept that Rescue-aspect to some degree as well.
(Aside from giving you a considerable advantage when it resolves on an opponent's permanent.)

88789: Ideas Unbound.author: EvilDarkVoid
88789: Ideas Unbound.text_parsed: @LunarAvenger: Sundial of the Infinite skips your next end step, so it never occurs and you won't have to discard at the end of your turn. However, there's nothing actually negating the effect of Ideas Unbound, just delaying it, so at the next applicable moment (usually the start of your opponent's end step) you'll have to discard the cards. So all it does is let you discard at the end of your opponent's next turn, not your own. Not totally useless but not as good as people were probably thinking.
88789: Ideas Unbound.text_posted: @LunarAvenger: Sundial of the Infinite skips your next end step, so it never occurs and you won't have to discard at the end of your turn. However, there's nothing actually negating the effect of Ideas Unbound, just delaying it, so at the next applicable moment (usually the start of your opponent's end step) you'll have to discard the cards. So all it does is let you discard at the end of your opponent's next turn, not your own. Not totally useless but not as good as people were probably thinking.

88789: Ideas Unbound.author: DarkonCrack
88789: Ideas Unbound.text_parsed:
@EvilDarkVoid

You are 100% right in most senses. If you play Ideas Unbound and use Sundial to just end your turn, it will trigger at the next possible chance. On the flip side, if you wait until the delayed trigger from Ideas Unbound (which if I'm not mistaken it's a delayed trigger) goes on the stack at the beginning of your end step and activate Sundial in response to it, then the turn ends before the ability resolves and having already activated, shouldn't try to activate again. My buddy had a Sundial deck that abused cards like this. Was too good... too good.

88789: Ideas Unbound.author: JaxsonBateman
88789: Ideas Unbound.text_parsed: @DarkonCrack - you are correct. It is a delayed triggered ability, and it's only a one-off (compare to something like Ball Lightning which says "at the beginning of the end step", as opposed to "at the beginning of the NEXT end step"). Sundial of the Infinite works perfectly with it, as long as you wait for the trigger to actually trigger first, then end the turn in response, exiling the ability forever. Having just found out about Ideas Unbound myself, my first thought was that I want to revisit Sundial and see what I can do with it.
88789: Ideas Unbound.text_posted: @DarkonCrack - you are correct. 88793: Skyfire Kirin.author: TreeTrunkMaster
88793: Skyfire Kirin.text_parsed:
If I Splice onto Arcane, does that add to the converted mana cost?
For example, if I cast an Arcane spell with cmc 1 (like Lava Spike) and Splice onto Arcane paying an additonal 2 mana (for say Glacial Ray's effect), is that spells cmc 1 or 3?

Okay found the answer, figure I will add it in case anyone else wonders:
502.40c The spell has the characteristics of the main spell, plus the text boxes of each of the spliced cards. The spell doesn’t gain any other characteristics (name, mana cost, color, supertypes, types, subtypes, etc.) of the spliced cards.

88794: Gnat Miser.author: Aquillion
88794: Gnat Miser.text_parsed:
The problem with this card is that most of the time, reducing your opponent's hand size by one won't do anything. Most good decks play cards quickly and get down to four or less cards within the first few turns. Even on the first turn, your opponent can avoid it by playing a card and casting a spell -- and if they went first, it's probably never going to help you at all, for the whole game.

In large numbers or in combination with other cards it might hit harder, but that takes even longer and gives your opponent even more time to get their cards out. And that that point, why not just use direct hand destruction?

88796: Ivory Crane Netsuke.author: DrJack
88796: Ivory Crane Netsuke.text_parsed:
How can you guys think this card is not good? If you only have 7-8 cards in your hand, this is BETTER than Ivory Tower. There are ways to have seven cards in your hand besides not casting any spells. Guess you kids didn't know that.

We all remember how good the Ivory Tower was, right? Well, obviously not. You don't remember the games where one player was sitting there with more than 70 life. I'll bet you new players don't even think Library of Alexandria was a good card either.

If it doesn't have "Trample, Doublestrike, Vigilance, Haste, and Lifelink", then you children just don't even want to look at it. We could have renamed it "Phyrexian Colostomy Bag" and had some "hilarious" yuk-yuk Mark Rosewater text, or had a picture of an ugly, screaming ogre brutally dismembering goblins, and fiery explosions with oversaturated colors in the background, and then you kids would drool all over it and rate it 4.5/5 stars.

Surprisingly, skull collector is a not half-bad card from kamigawa. However, it didn't work too well at all with other kamigawa cards.

88799: Ebony Owl Netsuke.author: igniteice
88799: Ebony Owl Netsuke.text_parsed: I always forget the name of this card and simply refer to it as the Owl Nuke card. I think it would be much more interesting if it was 8 or more cards that triggered the damage. Otherwise it is a passive damage card that punishes your opponents for playing the game, rather than being a strategic card that forces you to keep their hands full. The difference between 7 and 8 is that, unless they have something that gives them unlimited hand size, you would need to force them to draw extra cards during your turn, instead of passively letting the game keep them at 7. With this coming out on turn 2 or even 1 (Sol Ring, Dark Ritual, etc.), it's an exceptional amount of damage for such a small price.

88799: Ebony Owl Netsuke.text_parsed:
In multiplayer (particularly EDH, as the early games tends to be pretty slow), drop a Sol Ring and power this bad boy out turn one. Assuming your opponents don't run a lot of 1-drops in their edh decks, it should hit most of your opponents at least once. But then again, everybody starts out at 40, so it is effectively just a free, albeit conditional, Shock.

...Forget that, just go with Forced Fruition. Also provides good tech against certain other cards. "You just played Enter the Infinite and passed the turn? Have fun taking 4 owl damage... also you're not using that card properly."

88799: Ebony Owl Netsuke.author: SnackyNorph
88799: Ebony Owl Netsuke.text_parsed: Based on the comments and rating, I'm guessing that Gatherer has never heard of Owling Mine, an absurd tempo deck that really should have not worked. I can't recall all the cards involved, but essentially you used Howling Mine, Boomerang, and other cards that returned their field and spells to their hand, force them to draw extra cards, ping them with Ebony Owl Netsuke every turn, then finally finishing them with Sudden Impact. This card is great in the right deck, and hilarious enough of a win condition that people legitimately played One With Nothing.
