88802: Maga, Traitor to Mortals.author: Gabriel422
88802: Maga, Traitor to Mortals.text_parsed:
This saw a fair amount of constructed play, and the reason was that it was a good finisher when you have 23+ mana and can tutor (using transmute) for 3 cmc, alongside Invoke the Firemind.

The deck (Heartbeat combo) starts with Heartbeat of Spring, and then every Early Harvest nets you lots of mana. Drift Phantasm turns itself into Early Harvest (or a finisher), while Weird Harvest gets you four Drift Phantasms, eventually gaining you way too much mana on one turn.
88802: Maga, Traitor to Mortals.text_posted:

88802: Maga, Traitor to Mortals.author: DarthParallax
88802: Maga, Traitor to Mortals.text_parsed:
This card is as powerful as I want it to be. Yes, he's an Important Legendary creature- Yes, he's a bit overpriced.

The definition of Power Creep is wanting every White Legend to be Akroma Angel of Wrath and Vengeance and Justice and Retribution, every Blue Legend to be Arcanis, Lord of Scrolls, the Mind Sculptor, every Black Legend to be the 6th son of the 6th son of the 6th son of Griselbrand, and so on and so forth.

He's powerful. He's older now. He's not really quite worth reprinting as a Mythic. But he's nice. He's still useable. And he's pretty old to still be useable. I feel like with the mechanics they chose for him, they costed him as aggressively as they dared. Almost always when they enter with X +1/+1 counters they have to start at 0/0 to be not seriously messed up. Check Thromok and Mikaeus the Lunarch.

Could they have kept him as is and taken one black mana off, or else let you gain the life they lose? Just..maybe...but I prefer caution for situations like these. Kokusho is banned in Commander, and Maga is not-- if you like playing your cards, who then is really the better Legend? I'd rather have a B card I can play than an A++++ card that will lose me friends if I own. :P

To the plane of Kamigawa, he's very terrible and threatening. To the Multiverse in general, he ranks about as one of Bolas' Minions on 'threat level to planeswalkers'. His stats reflect roughly that and his playability history *also reflects roughly that.

88802: Maga, Traitor to Mortals.author: SirMalkin
88802: Maga, Traitor to Mortals.text_parsed:
This guy's a lot of fun. I use him as my general in an EDH deck that runs Gauntlet of Power, Caged Sun, Extraplanar Lens Nirkana Revenant, Cabal Coffers, and Magus of the Coffers. It's always hilarious when this guy hits the board as a 30/30 or greater. Well, hilarious to me, anyway, especially if I follow up the next turn with an equally big drain spell like Exsanguinate.

Sure, it's easy to see him coming, but you'd be surprised how often people forget about him. Not to mention that Cavern of Souls set to Wizard or Human makes countering him a very difficult proposition.

88803: Choice of Damnations.author: teddythebenn
88803: Choice of Damnations.text_parsed:
the principal is so.. uh bizarre.

this is how it works folks.

me; choose a number
opponent; 'reads the card' (turn 7+ or less, meaning permanent number, 10 or less/more)
opponent; has 10 permanents, so chooses 11. (canceling the sacrifice, as 10-11= -1 = no sac)
me; u lose 11 life.

tah dah.. it works .. a choice.. literally.. even if your opponent uses his/her head, the greater the permanent number, the greater the life loss, so the best way is, to lose life, then lose a couple of useless permanents, which by late game, would be a few lands..

88803: Choice of Damnations.author: Mode
88803: Choice of Damnations.text_parsed:
I'd consider it too siutational, particularly for six mana.
Similar to Fact or Fiction, you're the one that makes the final choice, so that's definitely a plus.

But this won't do much against control decks, or decks that just don't run all that many permanents. Sure, this will usually destroy at least a couple of lands in the process, but other times you'll just end up letting your opponent lose 5 or 6 life rather than saccing a permanent or two that he doesn't need that urgently.

There are more reliable cards to choose from that are either more destructive or make your opponent lose about as much life.

However, I really do like the design and the flavor behind it, and it looks like an excellent, fun card in multiplayer, which also makes it more likely that you'll find a "good victim".

88804: Trusted Advisor.author: Mode
88804: Trusted Advisor.text_parsed:
A one-drop that enables bounce effects for free each turn can't be half bad.
There really are some cards that are great to combine with him.
As opposed to Umbilicus or Blood Clock, you can now start your bouncing shenanigans with just one blue mana next turn. (Even though that restricts you to blue creatures and that your opponent won't have to bounce as well :P)

Mistbind Clique is a good target for him to create a soft lock.
Especially since Cloud of Faeries and Spellstutter Sprite are both very great bounce targets for two mana and come in handy for the advisor as well. Untapping a City of Traitors or recasting a hard counter for a ton of cheap spells is both awesome.

Once the lands are tapped, Rishadan Cutpurse can be used to force them into sacrificing their permanents.
(Damping Engine can also work if your opponent tends to bring a lot of permanents onto the field.)

Sky Hussar is amazing in this deck for mana-free card advantage (Synergizes with -creatures like Crackleburr and Order of Whiteclay.)
Also try Magus of the Library and the obvious choice, Azorius Æthermage.

Æether Vial, Semblance Anvil or Animar, Soul of Elements can save lots of mana.

Nevermaker also works as soft lock (similar to gramps' black counterpart Skull Collector and Chittering Rats)

Creatures with echo often have great cip/etb triggers too. Unfortunately we only have Raven Familiar in blue - but that's a pretty good one at least ;)
(For other (echo) creatures you could use Painter's Servant, but i wouldn't recommend that.)

Court Hussar can do the same if you spash white, Sea Gate Oracle can it do a lesser version, Merfolk Wayfinder can get you Islands.

Coiling Oracle might be one of the best early choices by spashing green. Either card advantage or even mana ramp!
Gets crazy with Momir Vig, Simic Visionary.
Thalakos Seer can be your surrogate in a monoblue deck, or Kami of the Creskent Moon as a one-sided Howling Mine when used with the vial on your opponent's turn (and is advantageous in team play).

Trinket Mage (and Treasure Mage) allow repeated tutoring.

Erayo, Soratami Ascendant and Vengevine might be interesting as well, but would require some more building around it.

Whirlpool Rider can be used as Mind Moil-like effect.

Yet another card i'd like to mention since it's interesting: Phantasmal Sphere can be used to give your opponent 0/0s (or even 1/1s for ) each turn. Very interesting to trigger abilities. With Suture Priest, Sunstrike Legionnaire, Twilight Drover, Glissa, the Traitor, Toshiro Umezawa or Burning Sands for example.

Ertai's Familiar can mill you for three. Even if you don't bounce him he'll still mill you, which might be useful with Eternal Witness if you support her otherwise.

Riku of Two Reflections is a nice addition for the later game.

Ninja of Deep Hours (Mistblade Shinobi as Man-o'-War surrogate) is a nice bounce target as well, given that you have another evasive creature that allows using Ninjutsu.

Plaxmanta can be reused as response to creature removal (given that you paid )

Halcyon Glaze makes a cheap 4/4 flyer, given that you re-cast something each turn.
Good against aggro are Oona's Gatewarden (also synergizes with the Hussar and other faeries) and Flood Gate as increasingly strong Tremor against non-blue creatures.
Jolting Merfolk can repeatedly tap four creatures.

Merieke Ri Berit (easier brought in play with the vial) can be used to take control and immediately destroy a creature each turn.

Phantasmal Image is a flexible choice with low (re)casting cost that can even copy an opponent's creature - but consider you might not be able to bounce it then anymore.

Equilibrium suits in this deck and synergizes with gramps for repeated Unsummons.

88804: Trusted Advisor.author: Aquillion
88804: Trusted Advisor.text_parsed:
I think the reason people miss how good he is is because of the +2 hand size thing. People see that, think "oh, that's his ability", then read the return-to-hand thing as a drawback to balance it out. Since +2 hand size isn't really worth much, they say "well, that's not worth a drawback" and vote him down.

In truth, of course, the +2 hand size is mostly irrelevant, and you're probably running him for the bouncing ability. A one-mana reusable way to bounce your own creatures is pretty powerful, even limited to your upkeep.

Also, his 1/2 body isn't terrible for one mana. He won't accomplish much in that respect, but he can save you a bit of damage.

88808: Sunder from Within.author: PolskiSuzeren
88808: Sunder from Within.text_parsed:
nammertime, no.

I am going to go around offering up examples for people who like to use the term "strictly" when it comes to magic.

there is no such thing as a "strictly" better card. there are always cases when one is better.

like this. it's arcane. so you can splice onto it.

you have six mana up, and play this while splicing on desperate ritual. Now you've destroyed a land, sitting on three mana, and have that ritual still in hand. use two of the R you have to cast it, now you're sitting on RRRR, and you can cast another one of these. so, in the long run, you only tapped down six lands, and played two 4 mana land destruction spells. and if you had two desperate rituals in hand, you could do it with only 4 land, by playing one desperate rit and splicing the second onto it, then proceeding as normal.

that situation is nowhere near a corner case, I could produce that situation plenty of times in a deck built around arcane and splicing.

good day.

88808: Sunder from Within.author: leomistico
88808: Sunder from Within.text_parsed:
@allmighty_abacus:
Maybe you're right, but with a Sire of the Storm in play PolskiSuzeren would have drawed 2-3 cards...

@Atali:
I defend Arcane cards ESPECIALLY for the Splice mechanic... It represents a way to build your own spell, combining various effects in a single spell. It's also quite resistant against counterspell, since you lost only the first spell, not the other that you spliced in the first.

The only problem is that they didn't a lot of spell really worth, so there are only a few alternatives, and there aren't arcane and splice cards outside Kamigawa block to combine with.

I agree that it's quite inferior to Pillage, but Pillage was very powerful, and you can't complain that a card is "strictly" worse than a already powerful card. In this trand you shouldn't play any "draw card" spell, since it's "strictly worse" than Ancestral Recall

88811: Scroll of Origins.author: majinara
88811: Scroll of Origins.text_parsed:
At first I thought the card is horrible, but then I started playing it in Commander / EDH decks, that have few carddraw (like mono red or mono white). There it's not bad, especially when you play it on turn two. Since you start with 8 cards no matter if you go first or not, playing this on turn two will allow you to keep drawing an additional card from turn three on, for a very low cost.
Sure, when you topdeck it late game it's pretty bad. But many cards are pretty situational, and I think the card is worth it's slot in EDH / Commander decks that are low on card draw.

88811: Scroll of Origins.author: Cyberium
88811: Scroll of Origins.text_parsed:
Is 4 mana worth while for your first draw? Even assume you have seven cards in hand when you cast this, it's hardly worth it. Library of Alexandria was powerful because it's a land, not only it couldn't be countered, its effect was free. Given the same requirement, the Scroll asks for too much.

If you are running an aggro or burn deck, you won't find seven cards in your hand aside from the beginning. LoA could draw cards early on whereas Scroll cannot be used early enough. If you play control deck, you would have methods of card draw with or without the scroll.

88817: One with Nothing.author: DarkbladeWraith
88817: One with Nothing.text_parsed:
A very weak card, but not entirely without it's uses. It fuses nicely with surprise use of the Hellbent mechanic, and more than a few cards in the Shards of Alara Block. If you have Sedris, the Traitor King already in play and a handful of expensive creatures, for example, for 1 mana you suddenly have a graveyard full of very cheap creatures to chose from. You can also give Lord of Extinction a quick boost, if he's looking a bit fragile or you just need one or two more P/T to make the difference between losing your creature and killing your opponent's.

Okay, not brilliant ideas and about 4 years too late, but it's better than it used to be! =)

88817: One with Nothing.author: kakosguitar
88817: One with Nothing.text_parsed:
A few years ago, when Kamigawa was out, I was excited to open a pack of the new expansion, Saviors. The commons were decent, and the uncommons were not horrible, but then I laid eyes on the rare. One With Nothing, i thought, well, that's an interesting name, and it's black for only one swamp! Let's see what it does! I read the text, and read it again. Are you kidding me? I thought. "Discard your hand." I sat there for ten minutes, grasping at straws for reasons why Wizards could have possibly printed this card. I came up short.
It's not even that this shouldn't be a rare, it simply shouldn't be a card! Yeah, you could say it would work in a madness or treshold deck for either turn one cheap spells or turn one threshold. Great. Turn two rolls around and you draw either a) a land, which you play then pass, or b) a useful nonland card which you can't even play because all you have is a swamp! I was so sad. 0.5/5

88817: One with Nothing.author: Fenix.
88817: One with Nothing.text_parsed:
One with Nothing may be my favourite Magic card ever.

I don't plan to play with it, and I don't find it particularly useful either. But I am fascinated by cards that cause an emotional reaction in me. And there is no card as shocking and (as ratchet1215 said), infuriating. When you first see it you feel like punching it through the screen, then you read the flavor text and after a few seconds, you are left in awe.

5/5

88817: One with Nothing.author: MyrBattlecube
88817: One with Nothing.text_parsed:
I love this card if only for how I've seen some of the fans react to it.
The newbies see this and think: "Wait, that's stupid."
The experienced tryhards see the newbies and berate them with: "No, you're just a stupid newbie. There are times when you need stuff in your hand in your graveyard and this is a great way to do it."
Of course, the players who know what they're doing see this and think: "There are better ways to dump the cards I need in my hand in a more precise fashion. I guess there are a few cases where this might do a better job, but on the whole this is stupid."

88817: One with Nothing.author: Ferlord
88817: One with Nothing.text_parsed:
Me and my friend created a new game format among our friends.

It's called Duel for Nothing.

What happens is that you play a game with any deck size.

You then replace 4 cards of your deck with One with Nothing. If you want to try it in EDH, still include 4 One with Nothing's.

If you have One with Nothing if your hand at ANY moment (opening hand or your draw it or you tutor for it (why? You tell me!)) you MUST play it. It is uncounterable, and costs .

It will be a cruel game of, "Oh yeah! All I need is one land, and... NNNOOO!!!!".

Then, and ONLY THEN will you ever experience being One with Nothing

88817: One with Nothing.author: kiseki
88817: One with Nothing.text_parsed:
Goes well with a new card from Gatecrash: Enter the Infinite (Draw your whole deck, put one card back, no max hand size).
So what you do is cast Enter the Infinite. Next turn do the following:
1) Draw last card
2) Tap 7 lands, cast Jokulhaups
3) Cast Tormod's Crypt
4) Cast One with Nothing
5) Sac the crypt targeting yourself (note that it will be in the graveyard and exile itself)

Result: No cards in hand, library, graveyard or in play. You have become completely one with nothing. Imagine the looks on your opponent's faces! Then reality sinks in, and they realize that they have to keep playing, and they have nothing left in play either...

88817: One with Nothing.author: DarthParallax
88817: One with Nothing.text_parsed:
This card does not suck. You're all just hating on it because you're embarrassed about flaming the hell out of it, then 'oops!' looks like someone discovered it's actually completely abusable. This warrants 3 stars at a minimum for teaching everyone to never mock an innocuous so blindly again. Yes, the particular thing this card does can be done better by some other things...but few cards influenced the way people thought about cards in general more than this one. One With Nothing let the cat out of the bag: the wierd cards are awesome, and you should get all the copies your snooty dumb buddies turn their noses up at, because you never know what's going to be the next Memory Jar. It was not the first to shape people's thought's: it joins the noble ranks of Necropotence, Doubling Season, Morphling, Lightning Bolt, and I'm having difficulty thinking of others that really defined as encompassing Worldviews about MAGIC. That is a Short List. Oh yeah, Lion's Eye Diamond and Ichorid.

1.Cards are worth Life.
2.The Fastest Deck Wins.
3.Get as Much of everything as Possible.
4.Creatures with tons of Abilities are like Spells on Sticks.
5.The Graveyard is a Resource.
6.No price is too high for the right amount of mana.
7.The Wierder the Card, the Greater the Advantage gained by 'cracking' it.

I'm trying to think of any other really big concepts that single cards represent.
I think those are all the "Fundamentals" though. You need lots of practice to identify good cases from mediocre cases, but those 7 Rules will build you almost all the decks you'll ever want to build.

88817: One with Nothing.author: psychichobo
88817: One with Nothing.text_parsed:
This card bugs the hell out of me for being at the wrong rarity, and I'm not talking about power.

Think about it. This card could be three things: Rare, Uncommon, or Common (disregarding Mythic for now, wasn't around then and couldn't be one anyway due to the power level).

As a Rare, it annoys people who get it since it's so brutally narrow - very effective in the right decks, but does bugger all for most others. Could've been a much cooler or more interesting card from that set, but sadly this is not the case. People who do want it will struggle to get a lot too, as it's a rare (unless you buy online).

As a common, you'd be have loads of these and it would have no useful purpose whatsoever in the draft scene, especially in a pure Saviours draft (auto-correct won't let me spell it the heretical American way). It'd just be a weird card you'd see loads of.

But at Uncommon? You'd get maybe one or two, you'd still have your shiny rare, and you wouldn't be overloaded with them. You could trade them easily with the people who do want them. Everyone would be happy.

Such a strange, strange card... can't deny it has uses though.

88817: One with Nothing.author: blazestudios23
88817: One with Nothing.text_parsed:
I don't get how this is rated so low, this is a black card people. Think about it. Turn 2, cast 2 dark riturals. Cast a tutor, then cast this in response. Empty the Eldrazi out of your hand. Tutor animate dead. And there is your Eldrazi turn 2 plus a whole not more cards in the grave you could use later. This is the ultimate play from the grave card.

It's also a great counter to Balance and any card that makes players have the same hand size or draw the same number of cards you have, and since it's block like I said you can play your cards from the grave they most likely can't.

And "One with Absolutely Nothing," would be the most broken card ever made. There are cards that bring every creature from your grave into play, and cards that bring every enchantment and artifact from your grave into play, you know that right? As long as you can give you creatures haste which would be super easy, you would win the game that turn.

88817: One with Nothing.author: GordonFreechmen
88817: One with Nothing.text_parsed: When I first saw Storm Crow I thought what the hell are you doing Wizard? This has to be the most broken card ever. Then I saw Chimney Imp, now at first I didn't think it was that good, but then someone pointed out to me it untaps for free during your untap step. It was like my mind was blown, now I know what they call him the Chimney Pimp. Definitely the best card ever right? Wrong, here comes One With Nothing. First off it combos with Mox Jet allowing you to play it Turn 1. That's right you can play this thing turn one with that insane combo. What's that didn't draw it, well luckily for you there is Demonic Tutor. Everyone knows with a card like this it is best to get it out as early as possible. Now I know a lot of you are saying, well yeah you can play it turn one with the Mox Jet super combo, but what is the point of discarding your hand? Let me ask you something how many times has your opponent played a card like Grixian Probe on you? Or Distress, or Duress, or Blood Oath? Let me tell you it happens. Your opponent gets to see all the cards you have to use against him. With This card they get to see nothing. Its like they wasted a card. Jokes on you opponent I have no hand. You just wait til next turn I am gonna draw something and possible if I have the mana play it, and you aren't going to have any idea what it is. Just think about that if you play against someone who uses this, you have no idea what's coming. You only option is to scoop.

88818: Hidetsugu's Second Rite.author: DarthParallax
88818: Hidetsugu's Second Rite.text_parsed:
In response to the lifegain guy:

Hidetsugu's Second Rite, meet Elixer of Immortality.
Elixer of Immortality, meet Flames of the Bloodhand.

Thank you Kamigawa, Thank You.
Sincerely,
Red

Hidetsugu is more combo than aggro, but red is the beautiful color where those two mean basically the same thing, and its hard to imagine a red deck that wouldn't want to splash one or two of this on the off chance they get the combo randomly.

Black-Red loves it the most. Sorin Markov FTW, and while you're in those colors, Thought Hemorrhage and Blightning are just neato.

88818: Hidetsugu's Second Rite.author: Guest1582708567
88818: Hidetsugu's Second Rite.text_parsed:
Our local Cube Draft has this interesting house rule: Whenever you cast one of it's few wish spells (like Living Wish, Glittering Wish, Burning Wish), instead of your sideboard cards, you may pick any card from Magic's history with the correct type. The rule states also, you can't use gatherer to search the card first. Some examples of this rule would be Living Wishing for Library of Alexandria or Burning Wishing for Damnation.

Few days back, when cubeing I had lots of mana Cunning Wish in hand and my opponent cracked an Arid Mesa when he was at 11.

He actually didn't believe this card existed.

88821: Measure of Wickedness.author: Ragamander
88821: Measure of Wickedness.text_parsed:
This card is so much fun!

Leyline of the Void (or Wheel of Sun and Moon) stops opponents from giving it away. Leyline of Sanctity (or Runed Halo, True Believer, Solitary Confinement, Witchbane Orb, Spirit of the Hearth, or, even better in team games, Imperial Mask) stops opponents from giving it back to you. And even if they did manage to give it back, any instant will stamp it with a big, red, "return to sender" label and blow it up right in their face.

However, I think I prefer Sundial of the Infinite to skip the trigger, then Silence during their upkeep. And maybe Copy Enchantment and/or Replenish/Auramancer to go the distance?

I really want to include some sort of instant-speed Flicker effect so that I can use one Measure of Wickedness twice (exile it in response to the trigger so that it can't be sacrificed but the controller still loses 8 life), but it's awkward without Leyline of Anticipation (or similar). That Leyline would be good for dropping Measure during their turn (i.e. second main phase), so you don't risk your opponent blowing up your Sundial or otherwise disrupting your plan: the additional benefit being that there is less they can do to stop it once they've already used some of their resources for the turn. Rather, I'm thinking about Mimic Vat and Leonin Relic-Warder/Flickerwisp/Glimmerpoint Stag, which already interact well with the Sundial.


@Dream_Spinner: Reread Leyline of the Void. It only affects opponents. If it hit everyone, it would work better with Energy Field.

88821: Measure of Wickedness.author: N03y3D33R
88821: Measure of Wickedness.text_parsed:
Having a little trouble understanding how this card works with ownership/controller.
So, you play this, lose 8 life and sac it at the end of your turn.
Next time a card goes into your graveyard it goes back into play under target opponents control and they lose 8 life at the end of their turn and sacrifice it. But then it would go back into YOUR graveyard since you are the owner. Does the first effect still trigger for them if it's now in your graveyard and no longer under their control?
88821: Measure of Wickedness.text_posted:
Having a little trouble understanding how this card works with ownership/controller.

Next time a card goes into your graveyard it goes back into play under target opponents control and they lose 8 life at the end of their turn and sacrifice it. But then it would go back into YOUR graveyard since you are the owner. Does the first effect still trigger for them if it's now in your graveyard and no longer under their control?

88821: Measure of Wickedness.author: Yukikah
88821: Measure of Wickedness.text_parsed:
@N03

This card says nothing about coming back from the graveyard. The trick to it is that it's only sacrificed at the end of your turn; You don't play it, lose 8 life, and sacrifice it. Instead you play it, and if you still control it at the end of turn you lose 8 life and sacrifice it. Hopefully, between the time you play it and your turn ends you'll have put a card into your graveyard and given control of it to your opponent (who then would sacrifice it at the end of their turn if they're not able to give it back to you before then).
88821: Measure of Wickedness.text_posted:
@N03

This card says nothing about coming back from the graveyard.  The trick to it is that it's only sacrificed at the end of your turn;  You don't play it, lose 8 life, and sacrifice it.  Instead you play it, and if you still control it at the end of turn you lose 8 life and sacrifice it.  Hopefully, between the time you play it and your turn ends you'll have put a card into your graveyard and given control of it to your opponent (who then would sacrifice it at the end of their turn if they're not able to give it back to you before then).

89399: Cloudhoof Kirin.author: psychichobo
89399: Cloudhoof Kirin.text_parsed:
I've actually found milling to be nice as a kind of side effect - like with the Sword of Body and Mind. Sure, you can argue it does nothing as you never really know if you stop them getting their good spell or help them get it, but it's nice when it's noncommittal.

Basically, pay 5, get a 4/4 flyer, and then if the game drags on there's reasonable odds you've punched your opponent's library hard enough for them to begin to be concerned. Admittedly 1 might not do much, but 2 would be very annoying.


I do play slow multiplayer games though, I will point that out.

89400: Descendant of Kiyomaro.author: Ataraxiom
89400: Descendant of Kiyomaro.text_parsed:
This is such a great card to use against aggro decks.

You're almost guaranteed to have a larger hand than an aggro player, and the 3/5 pseudo-lifelinker stats will drive them crazy. It's too big to burn up effectively, and attacking with a swarm will just result in losing attackers and dealing less damage because of the lifegain on this guy.

Being a three-drop might make it a little too slow to use against the fastest aggro decks out there, though.

89402: Glitterfang.author: DoctorKenneth
89402: Glitterfang.text_parsed:
@EvilCleavage ad Quang:

This gets returned from play to your hand at the end of the turn. It would not trigger from your graveyard or from any other zone. So if this DOES get destroyed (combat damage, etc), it will both go to and stay in the graveyard. Otherwise, if it lived through the turn, it gets bounced.

"When a creature comes into play" effects are obviously one route to take, as it has been mentioned (Pandemonium, if you're running with a theme). Red seems to be a good colour for this sort of tactic - see Viashino Sandstalker and others. Obviously, there are better ways to build around this than a Pandemonium fueled one-point-per-turn, but for some reason that just seems like a really fun casual deck.

89402: Glitterfang.author: igniteice
89402: Glitterfang.text_parsed:
Run with four Cinder Pyromancers for 20 damage per turn. Tap all four Pyromancers for the initial 4 damage, then play 1 Glitterfang at a type to untap them all and deal another 4 damage. After the fourth Glitterfang has been played, you deal the last 4 damage, for 20 total, then all four Glitterfangs return to your hand. Next turn you'd only be able to do 16 damage, but its a pretty brutal combination.

One of the drawbacks of this card though is that it is easy fodder for Honden of Night's Reach. You must pick up Glitterfang (unless you attack with it and it is killed), so during your opponent's upkeep, you're pretty much guaranteed to lose it (if you have no other cards to discard).
